title: Beating Myself up for Feeling Bad Never Changed Anything

content: For as long as I’ve dealt with depression, you'd think I wouldn’t be surprised when it sneaks up on me. You’d think I’d recognize the signs and acknowledge them right away, but the truth is, I often wonder why I’m feeling so bad.
Why am I so sad? Why do I have such a hard time finding anything good in life? Why do I just want to give up sometimes?

Instead of recognizing that it's depression talking instead of my own thoughts, I start to beat myself up. Why can’t you just be happier? Why can’t you look on the bright side and feel joy in your life? Why do you have to be so down and miserable so much of the time?

The more I think this way, the more miserable I get. I lose what little will I still have to give effort to the day, to try to find joy where I can. Yet even though I know this doesn’t help, every time the depression creeps back in, I start the cycle over.

content: Start feeling bad. Beat myself up. Tell myself how hopeless and pathetic I am and struggle to see any good. Realize it’s depression and I just have to deal with it and do my best. Repeat.

As I’ve gotten older, I think that one of the human traits we all need to be better at is treating ourselves the way we treat others, by treating ourselves the way we want others to treat us: with kindness, compassion, empathy, and understanding.

I sure need to work on this. I would never tell someone I love how awful and pathetic and miserable they are when they’re struggling to find happiness, but somehow, I feel like it’s OK when I’m telling it to myself.
For whatever reason, we seem to think that we have to be hard on ourselves to become better. So we beat ourselves up, thinking that will change things.

But if being a parent has taught me anything, it’s that when I criticize my child for something they’ve done, or when I make them feel bad about themselves, maybe not even intentionally, lasting change doesn’t happen.

But if being a parent has taught me anything, it’s that when I criticize my child for something they’ve done, or when I make them feel bad about themselves, maybe not even intentionally, lasting change doesn’t happen.

content: They might change their behavior, sure, but they’re doing it out of fear of what will happen if they don’t. They know that if they mess up again, they’ll have to face the consequences, one of which is an upset mother.

Yet criticizing them verbally sure doesn’t help them have good feelings about themselves. From what I’ve seen, in their minds, it shows them that because they did something bad, they are bad, whether I intended to make them feel that way or not.
And why would any kid who feels that way have any love for themselves?

Helpful feelings, good feelings that bring about positive change, don’t come from being beaten down. All beating someone down does is make them feel worse and worse about themselves until it’s hard for them to see anything good at all.

If I build my child up, on the other hand, even when they’ve done something they shouldn’t have, the response is remarkable. They change their behavior because they want to, not because they’re forced to. They know that they’re great kids who are learning what’s OK and what’s not OK, and nothing will stop them from loving who they are.

content: So if changing behavior with love is what changes things for my kids, why would it be any different for me? If I can talk to them in a loving way that shows them that just because they acted a certain way it doesn’t mean they are that way, then why don’t I do that to myself?

Instead of showing nothing but criticism for my thoughts and feelings and instead of beating myself up for constantly feeling depressed, maybe I should try a little compassion. A little kindness, a little understanding.
A little less need to change myself to feel the way I think I should be feeling, and a little more acceptance of how I am right then.
